comments.body: We use `<id>` for all other commands. We should be consistent, and convert them all to `<name>` at some point (soon).
Did you decide not to add commands to remove or change labels? Or do you imagine that would be done via flags?

At some point we should be worried about verb overload for new users - I think one lesson we took from our previous clients was that as the number of objects increase, having multiple verb forms of a command started to crowd the limited space in cli help.  When dealing with concepts that were common across all objects, having add-X and remove-X commands vs just the single "work with X" command detracted from initial usability.

> On Feb 7, 2015, at 11:48 AM, Brian Grant notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> In docs/kubectl.md:
> 
> > @@ -390,6 +390,7 @@ Additional help topics:
> >    kubectl run-container Run a particular image on the cluster.
> >    kubectl stop          Gracefully shutdown a resource
> >    kubectl expose        Take a replicated application and expose it as Kubernetes Service
> > -  kubectl label         Update the labels on a resource
> >   Did you decide not to add commands to remove or change labels? Or do you imagine that would be done via flags?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Changing labels is done by specifying the --overwrite flag

`kubectl label pods foo baz=bar --overwrite`

I hadn't thought about remove before, but now I'm thinking about:

`kubectl label pods foo baz-`

----- Original Message -----

> > @@ -390,6 +390,7 @@ Additional help topics:
> >    kubectl run-container Run a particular image on the cluster.
> >    kubectl stop          Gracefully shutdown a resource
> >    kubectl expose        Take a replicated application and expose it as
> >    Kubernetes Service
> > -  kubectl label         Update the labels on a resource
> 
> Changing labels is done by specifying the --overwrite flag
> 
> `kubectl label pods foo baz=bar --overwrite`
> 
> I hadn't thought about remove before, but now I'm thinking about:
> 
> `kubectl label pods foo baz-`

I thought of this exact same thing for env vars, and a trailing minus seemed correct.
I'm fine with that, so long as we're consistent with the pattern. We're probably going to need a kubectl-conventions.md.
